hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

(NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

‚óæIn Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.‚óæPrimitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).‚óæ8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.‚óæNon-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.‚óæCharacteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.‚óæExamples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Working from home isn‚Äôt a fad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how we live and work. And it comes with substantial economic upsides. In our latest piece for The Conversation Australia + NZ, Ying Lu, Neil Sipe, and I show that remote work offers tangible financial benefits for employers and society. Lower office expenses, less commuting, increased productivity, and even public health gains ‚Äî the case stacks up well beyond lifestyle preferences or politics. We use secondary and proxy data for Brisbane at the height of the pandemic, when WFH peaked. The research will be published in a new book in this series, edited by Jan Anne Annema: https://lnkd.in/dg6hrA7Y. Thank you for your editorial guidance, Margaret Easterbrook. üîó https://lnkd.in/d9YiXtwn UQ School of Architecture, Design and Planninghashtag#WorkingFromHome hashtag#UrbanPlanning hashtag#Brisbane
